newsitem.title: DOMINICAN REPUBLIC: Rights mission cites overcrowded Dominican jails.
newsitem.headline: Rights mission cites overcrowded Dominican jails.

text.p: An Organisation of American States human rights delegation said on Thursday that the Dominican Republic's prisons were badly overcrowded and criticised the slow pace of the nation's justice system.
According to official data, there are 30 prisons in the Dominican Republic designed to hold 6,971 inmates, but they currently house more than 11,000 people.
But the OAS's Inter-American Commission on Human Rights said the most serious problem in the nation's prisons was the amount of time it took for people arrested to be tried.

Prisoners "live in very difficult conditions," Alvaro Tirado Mejia, an official travelling with the mission, told reporters. "The problem is a result of severe overcrowding and a justice system that does not function as quickly as it should."
The mission had been in the Dominican Republic since Monday, and operated with the government's cooperation.

The most well known of the nation's prisons is La Victoria near Santo Domingo, where about 3,000 prisoners are being held in a 40-year-old facility intended to hold only 800. La Victoria, constructed during the dictatorship of Rafael Victoria, has seen several riots in recent months.
